Award.AwardTitle: Multi-Decadal Global Surveys of Benthic Nepheloid Layers
Award.AbstractNarration:
An accurate knowledge of the abundance and distribution of suspended particles in the ocean is essential to the study of marine biogeochemical cycles, especially trace elements and isotopes that interact with these particles. Particles in the benthic nepheloid layer (BNL), a layer of ocean water just above the seafloor, can accumulate radionuclides that are used in studying past global changes, as paleo-proxies, and in investigating modern and glacial ocean circulation. This project aims to assess the relationship between global maps of benthic nepheloid layers and surface and deep sea kinetic energy to document how these processes influence deep-sea processes of sediment resuspension and redistribution. Results from the research will be shared broadly with the oceanographic community. A graduate student who qualifies for the National Science Foundation Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Program would be supported and trained as part of this project.

Over the past 35 years, the investigators have collected more than 8000 transmissometer - an optical instrument calibrated to estimate particle mass - profiles from conductivity-temperature-density casts on approximately 70 cruises. These archived and ongoing collections of transmissometer data along with nephelometer data from the Lamont Doherty Earth Observatory, are the only collections of particle distributions in the ocean encompassing significant temporal and global scales. The main goals of the project are to 1) convert beam attenuation data to mass concentrations, 2) integrate the Net Standing Stock (NetSS) for each of the thousands of profiles, 3) map the NetSS globally from the 1980s-to-2016 transmissometer data, 4) compare these maps against global distributions of nephelometer data from the 1960s-1980s for which a preliminary global map has been constructed, and 5) compare nepheloid layers along 9 Repeat Hydrography lines where multiple cruises have occurred. The global maps (and supporting data) of the benthic nepheloid layers will be widely disseminated to the oceanographic community, enhancing the scientific understanding of BNL formation, decadal persistence, and their relationship to kinetic energy regimes for studying, deciphering and modeling biogeochemical cycles through the water column and near the seafloor.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Multi-Decadal Global Surveys of Benthic Nepheloid Layers

Global maps of seafloor particulate matter (PM) concentrations over five decades-long periods provide evidence that there are large areas of either persistently high or persistently low concentrations referred to as nepheloid layers (turbid water). Time-series PM measurements from multiple areas encompassing a wide range of integrated nepheloid layer PM concentrations strengthen the hypothesis that resuspension is common and episodic (benthic storms) in areas of high PM and rare or non-existent in areas of low PM over modern annual to decadal time scales.  Areas of high PM and benthic storms are more likely to occur where surface and benthic kinetic energy are high. Our invited review paper for Marine Geology (Gardner, W. D., B.E. Tucholke, M.J. Richardson, and P.E. Biscaye, 2017: Benthic storms, nepheloid layers, and linkage with upper ocean dynamics in the Western North Atlantic, Marine Geology; https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.margeo.2016.12.012) demonstrates the strong links between benthic storms and upper ocean phenomena that have been observed and explained by physical oceanographers; i.e. meanders and rings of the Gulf Stream generate cyclones and anticyclones whose energy can propagate to the seafloor. This linkage with upper ocean dynamics creates currents strong enough to erode and resuspend seafloor sediments. The Atlantic Deep Western Boundary Current is too slow to create benthic storms, but the mean Boundary Current flow could augment or retard the local cyclonic/anticyclonic flow and the Boundary Currents can then transport the resuspended sediment long distances before it is deposited down current. The relationships that we have observed in our detailed analysis of conditions and events in the Western North Atlantic Basin have been our guide in interpreting the global distribution and dynamics of benthic nepheloid layers.

Identifying areas of elevated nepheloid layer concentrations and higher abyssal energy is of interest in its own right for understanding ocean dynamics and sediment transport, but ?an accurate knowledge of the abundance, distribution and composition of particles in the ocean is essential to the mission of the GEOTRACES program, an international study of the marine biogeochemical cycles of trace elements and their isotopes www.geotraces.org? (Boss et al., 2014).  Okubo et al., (2012), Hayes et al., (2014) and Deng et al., (2014) have demonstrated that high resuspension activity increases the scavenging of adsorption-prone elements/isotopes like Th and Pa, which are used in quantifying particle fluxes and sedimentation rates, in identifying areas of trace metal and isotope scavenging, and mixing in boundary and interior deep waters. ?The mounting evidence for enhanced near-bottom scavenging from GEOTRACES . . . should motivate the marine geochemical community to examine these processes in greater detail.? (Anderson and Hayes, 2014). We are now interacting and publishing with scientists who are using our data to answer some of these questions.

Deep-Sea Mining

Deep-Sea Mining for valuable minerals and elements is already under way in several parts of the ocean. The impact of extensive mining that will undoubtedly disturb the seafloor and increase the amount of sediment in the water column is a major concern regarding benthic organisms and ecosystems. Our findings provide a global baseline which scientists and international regulators can use to estimate whether an area has higher concentrations of particles in the water than occurs naturally. We have provided data and maps that were used in a meeting of the International Seabed Authority for a workshop in Fall, 2019 that was evaluating potential mining impacts in the Deep Clarion-Clipperton Zone (CCZ).

Arctic Ocean

Strong nepheloid layers exist along the Arctic shelves as water enters from the Pacific Ocean through the Bering Straits and from the many Canadian and Siberian rivers onto the shelf. Some resuspended sediment is carried out into the Arctic basins where it settles. The deep Arctic basins do not exhibit strong bottom nepheloid layers, suggesting there are no strong bottom currents. Water entering from the Atlantic is cooled and sinks into the shallow basins of the Barents Sea, resuspending some sediment and moving it deeper in the shallow basins.
